column3: powerful book. I haven't come across a better book for a young or older mom to read. My wife handed me this book to read after reading it herself (and wiping away her tears). As you read this story
column4: you quickly see where it's going
column5: but that doesn't diminish the impact of the final pages. As much as I tried to remain stoic and composed (my wife was right there watching!)
column6: my face flushed
column7: a lump formed in my stomach and throat
column8: my eyes welled up with tears and (by the end) a few tears dripped off my nose. Perhaps I'm a softy
column9: but this book really has an impact. As much as I love my two sons and can't imagine anyone loving them more
column10: this book opened my eyes to how special and unique the love between mother and son is."^5^January 11

^16658937^1^2^"The book Wonder is a touching story from the author R.J. Palacio.  Wonder is a major motion picture that is about a boy with facial deformities and the struggles he faces.  I thought that it was a great book showing that you should never judge somebody by how they look.
August Pullman
column3: Jack Will
column4: Summer and Julian are  the main characters. Their school
column5: Beecher Prep
column6: is the main setting for the story.  The main conflict is among the characters who want to be August’s friend and those who always want to make fun of him.  The conflict is finally resolved when the fifth grade class goes to an overnight camp.  At the camp August and Jack are being bullied.  Classmates join together to help fight the bullies.  At this point all of the other students realize that Auggie is a normal boy and want to be his friend.

column1: The protagonist is Jack Will.  In the beginning of the book he is August’s friend because the principal firsts introduces the two boys and asks Jack to be friends with August.  Then on Halloween
column2: August walks into class to overhear Jack talking badly about August with some other boys.  This upsets August and he doesn’t want Jack to be his friend.  Once Jack realizes why Auggie is mad at him he apologizes and they become friends again.  Jack is an important character because he is the one friend who is always there for Auggie.

column1: I really enjoyed this book because of its message and how it makes everyone aware that we shouldn’t judge people by their looks.  I didn’t enjoy reading the part when the kids were making fun of Auggie and acting like he had a disease.  I felt sorry for him during this part.  This book is unique because it sends a heartfelt message to kids about being kind to others.  The author could have written more about what August did after school ended.  I was enjoying the book and didn’t want it to end.  I would definitely recommend this story to others because of the awesome message it conveys about being kind to others.  Everyone should read this book!"^5^January 26

column2: ^390907^19^2^"I have been trying to teach my girl (since she's 4 and a half) using Hooked on the Phonics for half a year. We are getting no where. She's frustrated; I am frustrated. It made her cry when I said it's time to do reading lesson.

column2: ^390907^13^1^"This book exceeds my expectations. I cannot comment on my child's reading success at the moment because we have only been using this for a few days. However
column3: this is sort of a How to Teach Reading for Dummies book in my opinion. I don't have to review the lessons
column4: just read exactly what it says for me to say in the highlighted parts on the page. Super easy. This makes teaching easy and stress-free. My daughter enjoys the lessons and she can stay focused because they are only about 15 minutes long
column5: once per day. If you are looking for a book to help you teach your child to read
column6: this is it. All you need is 15 minutes of lesson time each day."^5^October 10

column2: ^390907^12^3^"This program is very easy to use for teaching young children to read. My child has learned to read quicly which is very motivating to both of us. Great value. Highly recommend."^5^January 28
^390907^11^0^"Over the past 25 years we have been teaching our kids to read using this book.

column1: The eldest learned quickly in K before we moved. First grade
column2: and a poor teacher/district set her back to not being able to read. We concluded it was our fault for allowing others to control our children's education. We decided to homeschool.

column1: When we founds this reading book
column2: it was almost instantly helpful. She took to it rapidly sometimes taking 2-3 lessons a day. By the end of that summer after 1st grade she had regained all her lost reading skills and was now easily surpassing children in the neighborhood in 2nd
column3: 3rd and even 4th grade.

column1: Fast forward 20 years and we are still using the same
column2: ragged book
column3: and it is still effective. Four other children have learned to read using it. Each retained and grew in reading skills well beyond equivalent public school peer grade level all their childhood and even the 12year old reads above college grad level.

column1: We are now using this same book to teach our two youngest children. The 7 year old reads better than public school kids 2 years older than he is and the 5 year old is becoming very impressed with his ability to read words where he once just saw random letters. Every day is a new discovery for him and his brother now just sits and reads actual books
column2: without pictures
column3: as often as he reads those with.

column1: To those advocating that this is not 'advanced' and suggesting other programs for older children. I say they are wrong. Each child will be ready to read and to learn to read at a different time. But
column2: think about it
column3: if the child has trouble reading 'advanced' is NOT what you want to throw at him or her.

column1: This set of lessons teaches the child to use one of the greatest advantages the human brain has
column2: pattern recognition. The child learns to recognize distinct patterns in the highly variable English language. It uses a slightly modified written symbolic representation of those sound patterns to make them easier to recognize and learn. It then moves the child
column3: once the patterns are learned through a logically simplified process of normalizing those new pattern recognition skills so that they can then read unmodified text with the same confidence and accuracy as they could the symbolic text.

column1: It's a really ingenious method that has worked for and continues to work for all seven of our children
column2: each with distinctly differing personalities and learning types.

column1: The older (now adult) children are already fighting over who gets the book for their kids. We plan to buy a copy of this same book for each of them."^5^December 9

column2: ^390907^10^2^"A friend recommended “Teach Your Child to Read in 100 Easy Lessons”
column3: when we received the book and started it
column4: it was hard to imagine how something so easy was going to have our daughter reading at the end of 100 days. We have not completed the book
column5: yet as we have watched the progress unfold it is becoming more and more clearer how this amazing book works. We are starting to see our daughter reading already! Every parent needs this book regardless if their child struggles to read or not this book is so simplistic
column6: yet so powerful…"^5^May 24

column2: ^390907^5^1^"If you are looking for something simple to use with your child who is interested in learning to read... this is it. The lessons are short to keep a young one's attention
column3: use visual tricks to teach different concepts (ex: make the letter smaller than surrounding ones when it is silent in the word)
column4: have lots of review from lesson to lesson
column5: and progress quick enough where the child is learning to read simple words and sentences quickly."^5^March 8

column2: ^390907^5^2^"I borrowed this from the public library a few times and then decided to purchase it instead. Well worth the purchase. My daughter is 4 and she is already starting to be able to sound out words and we are only on the 7th lesson. I highly recommend it for beginning readers!"^4^May 14
^390907^5^3^"Our daughter has been struggling to learn to read and it hasn't 'clicked' for her yet and this book is helping me to help her accomplish this goal."^4^April 7
^390907^4^0^"This book has been amazing for my two oldest children. It fascinates me to see how they begin with such basic
column3: almost boring steps
column4: then progress to being able to read so swiftly. They feel a great sense of accomplishment in a very short amount of time. I am on lesson 20 with my third child and bought this as a gift for my sister for her children. Don't let the first few lessons discourage you
column5: and stick to the dialogue in the book. It's well-worth it! They start reading 'stories' after about 10 or 15 lessons
column6: and it gets more and more rewarding as they progress. The printed dialogue makes that parent/teacher's job easy and keeps you from getting frustrated--just stick to the text and you're good!"^5^July 12

column2: ^390907^4^0^"I've used this book to teach four of our children to read. It is excellent! Each one of them was reading at a 2nd grade level when finished with the book. The only complaint I've heard from others who use it as well is that the lessons can be somewhat redundant and the child
column3: of course
column4: doesn't like repetition. In my opinion
column5: however
column6: repetition is key. It also takes longer than 20min/day as you progress further into the book. Another drawback
column7: I found myself
column8: was the writing at the end of each lesson. However
column9: I just had my child skip that task. :) Also
column10: there are several typographical errors throughout the book
column11: but nothing that hinders teaching. My kids loved uncovering the pictures (you cover them up) with each story...it was great anticipation and made it fun."^5^November 13

column2: ^390907^4^4^"Great results

column2: ^51334262^4^0^"Much of the writing in THE SUBTLE ART OF NOT GIVING is tongue-in-cheek. Surprisingly
column3: however
column4: there is a lot in this book that is SERIOUS. I know
column5: I know
column6: with a title like that
column7: it's hard to believe
column8: but it's true. Mark Manson actually makes quite a few substantive
column9: helpful points.

column1: Mark makes it clear that he's NOT saying you should not care about anything. Not at all. What he is saying is that you should pick carefully WHICH things you care about:
'This book will help you think a little bit more clearly about what you’re choosing to find important in life and what you’re choosing to find unimportant.'
He's not suggesting we should be indifferent; rather
column2: carefully deciding where to place our concern.

column1: How you pick your top concerns has practical consequences. Mark gives a real-world example about a cranky person in the check-out line at the market. The elderly customer is making a big fuss about some minor thing. Why? Because they don't have anything else to occupy their time. If you don't have anything substantive to occupy your time
column2: then it's trivial stuff that bothers you:
how quickly the batteries die in the TV remote
column3: missing out on yet another two-for-one sale on hand sanitizer—chances are you don’t have much going on in your life...'

column1: Mark suggests just picking a few big things--values and people that reflect your values: 'What I’m talking about here is essentially learning how to focus and prioritize your thoughts effectively—how to pick and choose what matters to you and what does not matter to you based on finely honed personal values.'
Much of life is about solving problems. They are inevitable
column2: and we shouldn't pretend that we can make them go away. The author has no kind words for those embracing victimhood:

column1: 'People deny and blame others for their problems for the simple reason that it’s easy and feels good
column2: while solving problems is hard and often feels bad.'
the author relates a horrific experience from his youth
column3: when a drunken friend took a dare
column4: jumped into a lake and drowned.

column1: 'The most transformational moment of my life occurred when I was nineteen years old.' This tragedy led to a determination to change the direction of his life
column2: and figure out what is most important: 'Oddly
column3: it was someone else’s death that gave me permission to finally live. And perhaps the worst moment of my life was also the most transformational.'

column1: The last part of the book has a serious tone--quite different in tone than the first part of the book. This part of the book is more philosophical. The author refers often to a book
column2: 'The Denial of Death
column3: ' (which became a Pulitzer Prize winner.) In serious
column4: heartfelt chapters
column5: the author reflects on human existence
column6: and our search for meaning in life.

column2: I found THE SUBTLE ART to be a fascinating read. The author writes well
column3: and the book is easy to follow. Don't be fooled by the title; a lot of this book is very serious."^4^March 11

^392592^18^1^"I won't waste your time with a rundown of what 'How to Win Friends and Influence People' is about. With over 15 million copies sold
column3: and with a very self-explanatory title
column4: I think you all get it. For the rare person who may not know what this book is about
column5: here's a succinct description: in 1930s vernacular prose
column6: Dale Carnegie explains that by appealing to the other person's highest ideals
column7: remembering the other person's name
column8: letting the other person do most of the talking
column9: speaking in terms of the other person's interests
column10: allowing the other to save face
column11: by 'throwing down a challenge
column12: ' etc.
column13: you can make a friend out of just about anyone.

column2: but I think the reader should keep in mind the context within which this book was written. 'How to Win Friends and Influence People' was written in the 1930's and intended primarily as a companion book to Dale Carnegie's classes on how to be a good salesman. In other words
column3: these techniques work very well in the context of sales and public relations
column4: i.e.
column5: in relationships that are not expected to be deep and/or long-lasting. I wouldn't recommend using these techniques on close personal friends. Doing so may make a person come across as a bit 'plastic.'

column2: there is one major point that I think needs to be remembered
column3: but unfortunately is nowhere to be found in 'How to Win Friends and Influence People.' During my research of Dale Carnegie's techniques
column4: I came across what I believe may be the only biography available about him: Dale Carnegie: The Man Who Influenced Millions by Giles Kemp and Edward Claflin. This book reveals many interesting things
column5: such as the fact that Dale Carnegie grew up poor; he lost part of his left index finger when he was a child; he often broke many of the tenets set forth in this book
column6: often forgetting others' names
column7: often arguing with others
column8: etc. But what I found most interesting was that the last chapter of 'How to Win Friends' was to describe those individuals with whom none of Dale Carnegie's techniques work. In this unpublished chapter
column9: Carnegie wrote that there were some people with whom it was impossible to get along. You either needed to divorce such people
column10: 'knock them down
column11: ' or sue them in court.

column1: Why is that chapter absent from this book
column2: you ask? Well
column3: Dale Carnegie was in the middle of writing this chapter when he was offered a trip to Europe
column4: and rather than complete this last chapter he decided to take the trip. The uncompleted book was sent off to publishers
column5: and Carnegie shipped off to Europe.

column1: Giles Kemp and Edward Claflin say that given the optimistic tone of the rest of 'How to Win Friends
column2: ' the European trip was perhaps the better choice. Reconciling the the unwritten chapter with the rest of this optimistic book would've been nearly impossible
column3: they say.

column2: I think that this unpublished chapter is important to keep in mind. I had to learn the hard way that the unpublished chapter is very true. There are some people with whom it is impossible to get along. When you meet up with such people
column3: and believe me you will
column4: don't think that you've failed the Carnegie techniques. Instead
column5: remind yourself that you are experiencing exactly what Carnegie describes in that pragmatic
column6: unpublished chapter. And then quickly move on to the nicer people!"^5^September 11

column2: ^392592^8^0^"Since reading this book
column3: I feel like for the first time I have been given the basic instructions to approach obstacles in a positive way with a degree of confidence in a positive outcome. We have a child with Oppositional Defiance Disorder (ODD) and Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and we have been in therapy for 8 years with multiple counselors and psychologists with little to no improvement. She is frequently against anything and everything that we try to teach her or help her with and has no reaction to any type of discipline. In her mind she is always right
column4: always has all the answers and when something goes wrong she is always the faultless victim. I have frequently felt completely hopeless and overwhelmed
column5: and I have thrown up my hands and said that I have run out of ideas and answers about what we could do to help her. Now that I have read this book I have had floods of ideas in how I could approach day-to-day issues without getting as upset or trying to correct her behavior
column6: and I have found many faults in my previous methods which obviously were not working. I have just finished this book so I can't say that we have worked any miracles but I began applying these simple principles while still reading the book and we are already experiencing more pleasant behaviors and finding more enjoyment in our time together. I have already recommended this book to several friends and family members and I'm hoping that they read it and can benefit from it as I feel I have!"^5^May 14

^392592^1^0^"A classic (originally published in the 30's) and a must-have
column3: this timeless piece of work can help just about anybody get along better with others and win them over to their way of thinking. Don't have a lot of time to spare? Don't worry. The book is divided into short sections
column4: each one devoted to a particular principle that is well illustrated with many practical examples. In this way
column5: you can read a chapter quickly
column6: stop and do other things you have to do if necessary
column7: and get back to the book when you have time- all without losing continuity.

column1: Thoroughly entertaining by using fun and interesting examples
column2: I don't think many readers will regret checking this one out and I like to think of this book as a kind of Human Relations 101 of sorts. Also recommend 'The Sixty-Second Motivator' for further reading on motivational principles."^5^February 18

column2: ^438978^4^2^"This book won’t control your mind
column3: but it does have a lot to do with mind control. 1984 is a book written by George Orwell in 1949 depicting what Orwell believed that England would look like in the future. This book depicts a “Utopian” society that is ruled with an iron fist by the government who uses propaganda to control the population. Propaganda like “Big Brother is watching” is displayed on signs so that citizens know that the government is always watching and that the Thought Police are monitoring thoughts through “Tele-screens” (televisions). These Thought Police are used to track rebels who want to destroy the totalitarian government and bring freedom to the people.

column2: Winston Smith
column3: works for the government but sees the injustices going on around him. Winston breaks little rules here and there like writing a journal even though this is forbidden by the Thought Police. Winston works for the Ministry of Truth; a government building that changes history by “erasing” events from the past by changing photos
column4: editing books
column5: and completely removing people from history. The Ministry of Truth does this to control the knowledge of past successful rebel uprisings.

column1: This is a great book that gives a lot of insight on what life is like in our society
column2: even if we don’t recognize it on a daily basis. Orwell wasn't completely right with the date
column3: however
column4: I feel that our society is slowly reaching the point in which this book will no longer be “Fiction”. I would recommend this book to someone who is looking for a story with a deep history and speculation. I had a great time reading this and i think you will too."^4^December 14

column3: at some point describe

^2664290^20^0^"After reading happiness books like 'Finding Happiness in a Frustrating World'
column3: I felt like I had a good handle on what science had uncovered about how to live a happy life and have to say that I am MUCH happier for having read them. But
column4: while the field of positive psychology has made some great contributions to my happiness levels
column5: it's books like 'The Power of Now: A Guide to Spiritual Enlightenment' that come along and let you know there's STILL more you can learn.

column1: A key concept of the book (if I'm explaining it right) is that you will start to experience a certain kind of enlightenment when you learn to leave your analytical mind behind. In other words
column2: instead of 'thinking' try just 'observing your thinking.' And when you do this
column3: you also need to realize that all this 'thinking noise' that goes on in your head all day long is not really who you are- an enlightening concept indeed!

column2: the book is set up in a question and answer format to help you get to understand these kinds of concepts. While it might seem ridiculous to some
column3: it really isn't. Case in point
column4: we all talk to ourselves or have witnessed others talking to themselves at times (maybe during a sporting event perhaps). If you ask someone who they are talking to
column5: they will usually say 'I'm talking to myself.' And this
column6: by definition
column7: means that there have to be two 'selves'
column8: an 'I' talking to 'myself'- and so justifies the idea of two selves (a 'you' and a 'thinking you' in the book).

column2: if these seem to be the kind of concepts you're ready to explore
column3: this is your book. It raises some good questions and certainly brings up one that you can't argue with: all we have is the here and now. As the book so astutely points out
column4: 'Nothing ever happened in the past; it happened in the Now. Nothing ever happened in the future
column5: it will happen in the Now.' And learning to live in the now IS the point of the whole book."^5^January 28

column3: I am skeptical when I hear that everyone else likes a book or movie. I can't help to feel that it's being blown out of proportion and that it just can't be that good. This book is quite the exception.

column2: this unique book explores many deep themes including death and dying (no surprise)
column3: the power of words
column4: and the beauty of a good friendship. Liesel is a very well developed
column5: three dimensional character
column6: and the supporting characters only add to the amazing story. This book is different from other World-War II era novels
column7: as it takes the view point of a German child. Very little is mentioned about the horrors of the Holocaust
column8: but the book instead focuses on the average German during the war and also brings up several good questions
column9: such as 'Was it right for the Allies to bomb civilians?'

column1: Zusak proves to be a master of symbolism and metaphors - even the cover of the book (falling dominoes) symbolizes something far more treacherous. I've read this book three times
column2: and pick up on something new every time I read it. It is by far the best book I have ever read
column3: and I recommend it to anyone.

column1: Please don't skip over this book because it is labeled as 'young adult.' Just because the main character is a young girl doesn't mean only young girls can read this book. I think anyone
column2: any age could enjoy this book; however
column3: I think people over the age of 14 or 15 would get the most out of it.

column1: Can't wait to see the movie!! (comes out in 2010)"^5^March 13

column2: ^52842714^6^1^"The reason I decided to read the book thief because I saw there was a movie coming out about it. The trailer looked phenomenal and I have always loved books set in World War II. I purchased the book and I loved it! But loving it did not come automatically. It took me a couple of pages to realized who the narration for the tale was done by
column3: but once I realized that the narration is given by death who stays with Leisel to witness her life
column4: my view and expectations changed a bit and helped prepare me for the rest of the tale.

column1: I anticipated it to be much like other tales based in Germany World War II and immediately start into a tale of survival in a war zone. It came to be more of a story of self-discovery for a young Leisel who has been taken from everything she knows to foster parents. The father lovingly teaches her to read
column2: which she had always desired to learn
column3: and through her love of reading she finds strong connections with others and understanding in a world of chaos.

column1: A wonderful tale that through both the journey we take with our main character as well as pure literary genius helps us to fall in love with the written word all over again."^5^December 5

^2602524^1^0^"Twilight is a very excellent book. Stephenie Meyer is an awesome writer and this book really keeps your attention. You always want to keep reading and know what is happening next. This book is about a teen girl named Bella Swan and she moves with her dad in a small town named Forks. When there she meets this very odd but beautiful family. They were the Cullens. She had an encounter with one of the Cullens named Edward and he saved her from a van and stopped it with his hand! She knew that there was something odd there but she wasn't sure what. Of coarse i won't tell you more because I want you to enjoy the book. It is really an intreaguing book. Through the story she shares a wonderful love with Edward Cullen and they go through life threatening things together but they love each other and keep themselves going. You will very much enjoy this book with its romance but its addicting action as well. I have read all of the Twilight books and i am reading them again for a second time. I do recomend this book. I hope you enjoy it."^5^April 11
^2602524^1^0^"I absolutely love this book! Meyer is an excellent writer

column4: you may even have a hard time remembering that the story is fictional and not real. While reading this book I am 100% positive that you will be spellbound or entranced like myself. I literally couldn't put it down or continue with my daily routine until I finished it. I can say without any doubt that this is the best book I have ever read. The others in the series follow the same suit! Be sure to read them all
column5: you won't be disappointed!!!"^5^January 5

column2: ^4406976^2^0^"My fourth grader has read over 200 pages of this book during the last couple weeks. Although he prefers the 39 Clues serious for more action

column2: ^403453^9^2^"I have read hundreds of books on business
column3: Sam Walton's autobiography is one of the best without the academic jargon. It is simple

column5: and shows the character of a good and caring man. It also reveals the principles for success in business in a competitive environment. Years before they went bankrupt

column2: ^403453^6^1^"I felt compelled to check out “Made In America” by Sam Walton out of curiosity and pride with being a Walmart employee. I was exposed to some of Walton’s philosophy during my orientation and felt curious to check out more. The following are some of the tidbits included in “Made In America” by Sam Walton:

column1: Pages 1-3: He mentions how his life changed after interviewing with Forbes magazine in October 1985 (after he was named the “richest man in America). A harrowing experience is also recalled when he talks about being “ambushed by The Lifestyles Of The Rich and Famous Guy” at a tennis tournament.
Page 70: Jim Walton recalled how some writers thought that his father (Sam Walton) was a “grand strategist who psychically carried out plans and actualized them with precision”. However
column2: he mentions that the reality was that his father actually “thrived on change” when it came to many decisions.

column1: Pages 80-81: Sam Walton listed some of his family pictures such as those of this parents and grandparents
column2: as well as his wife
column3: children
column4: and a Ben Franklin franchise in Newport
column5: Arkansas.

column1: Page 95: Sam Walton created and wrote down a five year plan of the business ideas that he intended to accomplish. He mentioned that he saved these plans for a long time and found (several years later) that his target goals were exceeded by at least 15 to 20 percent.

Pages 240-241: There is an inclusion of more pictures from Sam Walton’s years with Walmart such as a happy picture of him with his wife Helen. There is also a fascinating 1990 feature of HillaryClinton as Wal-Mart’s Board of Directors.

There is also a postscript by Rob Walton due to the fact that Sam Walton was in the final stages of his life when writing this book. There is much more featured in “Made in America” by Sam Walton for those who are curious to know more about the founder behind Walmart and the actual company of Walmart."^5^November 29

column2: ^403453^6^1^"A must read for anyone. Mr Sam was an insightful man with a straightforward understanding of how to build a successful enterprise. His ideas can be applied to any business or personal relationships."^5^April 7

column4: my daughter however loved it and related to little Trixie. We've read this a million times. (sigh) The combination of illustration and photo is ingenious and What Willems lacks in style he makes up for in intuitiveness. Kids LOVE his books

column2: ^5772610^1^0^"Knuffle Bunny is a sweet story of a little girl Trixie who throws a tantrum because she misplaces her knuffle bunny in one of the machines. This is a great book to relate to students when they once upon a time lost something that they held dear to their hearts."^4^February 25
^5772610^1^0^"A book that resonates with the very young and their parents
column3: especially those who have a 'special' toy. The story is typical
column4: as Trixie heads to the Laundromat with her dad and then along the way loses her precious Knuffle Bunny. What makes this story unusual is Willems ability to portray Trixie's frustration (a laugh out loud 'boneless' episode that any parent will identify with being the highlight) and the unique artistic style of colourful cartoon characters set against black and white photos of the city. My daughters love this book"^5^July 27

column2: ^5772610^1^0^"An adorable tale of a young toddler (Trixie) who loves going to the laundromat with her Dad. During one of her visits
column3: she forgets her favorite stuffed animal at the laundromat
column4: and despite multiple (humorous) fits
column5: she fails to communicate what's wrong to her Dad. Dad eventually saves the day by retrieving the bunny-- and Trixie surprises everyone by exclaiming its name. Super book!"^5^July 23

column2: ^5772610^1^0^"Knuffle Bunny: A Cautionary Tale is a really great early reader book by Mo Willems
column3: who has a creative style of illustrating that is a sure eye catcher. When Trixie and her father go to the laundry mat
column4: there is a terrible occurrence when Knuffle Bunny goes missing. When someone
column5: or something we hold dear disappears
column6: we're not likely to take it well. Mo Willems uses illustrations over photography
column7: giving a wonderful new twist to the picture book. I really loved this book
column8: and highly recommend it to all readers and early grade classrooms."^4^October 22

column2: ^5772610^1^0^"This is an adorable story complete with unusual pictures that incorporate real world images with cartoon characters. Sure to catch any eye
column3: this story will keep the reader hooked with an active layout and loveable characters. The story is so well written -- as though you are in the mind of the child. It is sure to be a family or classroom favorite."^5^December 19

column2: ^5772610^1^0^"I discovered Knuffle Bunny only very recently at a library conference - and fell in love. It's very fun

column2: ^35394798^4^0^"In The Fault In Our Stars by John Green
column3: he builds a story out of darkness and despair. He takes the tragedy of cancer and immerses us in the lives of characters that could very well be real. Many know of the heartaches in dealing with those who fight the fight
column4: and many of those scars last a lifetime. He brings his story in the form of a teen girl
column5: Hazel Lancaster. Stricken with cancer from a young age
column6: she believes she has come to terms with what her life has become. Then she meets a young man
column7: Augustus Waters
column8: a survivor of cancer. He is drawn to her in a way that is initially uncomfortable
column9: and as she tries to push him away in her sarcastic vein
column10: he finds her to be exactly the type of girl he has been looking for. For cancer touches not just the victim but all those who have loved and are in anyway touched by them. One should be prepared for a story of romance
column11: anger
column12: excitement and humor
column13: and friendship and bravery for that is the way we are led as Green develops the personality of a group of teens that have the courage to bring both laughter and tears. Hidden within that strength they also hide the depression and hopelessness as they try hard to protect their family and friends by showing only the smiles and strength whenever possible. The friendships as well as the depths the families go through preparing for the worst while holding out hope is like a beacon of light.

column2: the energy and sadness all keep you on a roller coaster of emotion. Green takes you on a journey both terrible and beautiful."^4^October 28

^47876712^11^1^"If you're looking for a cookbook with recipes that include one or two items you use from your canning supply then this book is for you.  If you're looking for weird and wonderful (debatable) twists on your tried-and-true favorites then this book is for you.  If you're looking for a book with a handful of meal-in-a-jar recipes then this book is for you.  If you don't mind having to reheat your pie filling after you've dumped it out to make a pie
column3: then you guessed it...this book is for you.

column2: on the other hand
column3: was looking for a good basic canning guide with lots of recipes.  I already know how to can but it's a pain looking up the latest safety guidelines etc. for tomatoes or trying to find a resource I trust for things like pie filling using cook-type clear gel (so you don't have to heat the filling up and add thickener when it's time to use it).  Alas
column4: this was not the book for me as it tweaked basics like tomato juice and omitted any alternative to cornstarch as a thickener for pie filling.  It did include a good bone broth recipe...and a handful of basic charts for canning things like pears or green beans
column5: so it wasn't a complete waste.  I just wish they had included traditional recipes alongside their 'tweaked' ones so that I wouldn't have to keep looking for some of the basics time and again."^3^June 2

column2: ^659358^4^0^"Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets seems to be the least favorite book of many HP fans. However

column2: ^659358^1^0^"Harry Potter enters his second year at Hogwarts with a bang... literally. He crashes into a tree while flying a car to school. The second book in the series has never been my favorite
column3: but I was surprised
column4: upon re-reading it
column5: to discover how many small details foreshadow events in future books. They seem unimportant here
column6: but in retrospect Rowling was clearly setting up the final premise early on. There are also so many important characters that are introduced in this installment. We meet Dobby and see his eternal loyalty unfold from the first chapters. We meet the entire Weasley family (except the eldest brothers) and visit their home
column7: the Burrow
column8: for the first time. They truly become Harry's family and so this is an important event. We also see Dumbledore's office for the first time and his role becomes more prominent. This is also the book where Voldemort becomes more than just a generic baddie. Until now we knew nothing about his past. Learning about his heritage
column9: childhood and 'normal' years makes him an interesting adversary
column10: instead of just a villain. I love Harry's struggle with the similarities between him and his foe. It adds another great layer to the story. Rowling has an interesting habit of splitting up the core group at the end of many of the books. In the first one
column11: Ron is separated from Hermione and Harry at the chess game. In the second book
column12: Hermione is debilitated before the Chamber of Secrets sequence. In the third book
column13: Ron is again out of commission before the final section. I never really noticed that before
column14: but it's an interesting trend. Side note: What happened to Neville? He is barely mentioned at all in this book
column15: which is sad. A few things I'd forgotten about the second book: 1) This is the first time Harry is really disliked or feared by other students. In future books this happens frequently
column16: but this book marks the first time Harry is rejected by many of the people he knows in the wizarding world. 2) I'd forgotten all about Nearly Headless Nick's deathday party. It provides a chance to meet a few of the house ghosts
column17: which is important in the final books. 3) Fawkes is such a critical character in this book. I'd forgotten how crucial the phoenix's role is and how important it is that he comes when Harry needs him. ^659358^1^0^"Warning: This review contains spoilers. Harry's second year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry provides us with even more excitement and adventure than his first! Though the Harry Potter series is most definitely a children's/young adult's book
column3: the second one has much darker overtones than the first. Muggleborns are mysteriously being Petrified at Hogwarts and unless the culprit is found
column4: there's a good chance Hogwarts will close...for good because for every student ending up Petrified
column5: the odds are getting higher and higher that soon enough
column6: one will end up murdered. Harry also begins to exhibit a few traits associated with Dark Magic
column7: most notably his being a Parselmouth. Could it be possible that he's the Heir of Slytherin who's responsible for Petrifying innocent students? Overall
column8: I've always felt this book had more pure adventure and less emotional angst and whatnot than most of the other books. We see Harry develop some more on-the-spot problem solving skills as he must eventually enter the Chamber and fight the monster
column9: and we definitely see his bravery even in the face of what appears to be insurmountable odds. However
column10: I must say that while this book is just as much fun to read as the first in the series
column11: it is by no means my favorite. Yes
column12: it's packed with action and adventure
column13: but it seems to be the book least relevant to the culmination of the series. I'm not disregarding the importance of Riddle's diary
column14: but we are never told the importance of it until the sixth book so it seems to have little to no relevance to the series while reading it. There's also the lack of emotional connectivity in this book. There wasn't a good balance between the adventure and the emotional side of things
column15: I thought. There was too much mystery and excitement and not enough self-discovery. This might not bother some people
column16: but it's always bothered me (for what I always felt was an excellent balance
column19: and fifth Harry Potter books). Still
column20: it's an excellent book and I love it and I love to reread it. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who hasn't read it and if you have read it
column21: well I always think it's worth a reread!"^5^June 14
